elements.content: P2W18Co4@MOF-545, which contains the sandwich-type polyoxometalate (POM) [(PW9O34)2Co4(H2O)2]10– (P2W18Co4 ) immobilized in the porphyrinic metal–organic framework (MOF), MOF–545, is a “three-in-one” (porosity + light capture + catalysis) heterogeneous photosystem for the oxygen-evolution reaction (OER). Thin films of this composite were synthesized on transparent and conductive indium tin oxide (ITO) supports using electrophoretic (EP) or drop-casting (DC) methods, thus providing easy-to-use devices. Their electro- and photocatalytic activities for OER were investigated. Remarkably, both types of films exhibit higher turnover numbers (TONs) than the original bulk material previously studied as a suspension for the photocatalytic OER, with TONs after 2 h equal to 1600 and 403 for DC and EP films, respectively, compared to 70 for the suspension. This difference of catalytic activities is related to the proportion of efficiently illuminated crystallites, whereby a DC thin film offers the largest proportion of POM@MOF crystallites exposed to light due to its lower thickness when compared to an EP film or crystals in suspension. Such devices can be easily recycled by simply removing them from the reaction medium and washing them before reuse. The films were fully characterized with extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) and X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectroscopies, Raman, scanning electron microscopy, and electrochemistry before and after catalysis. The combination of all of these techniques shows the stability of both the POM and the MOF within the composite upon water-oxidation reaction.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted immense research interest in the design of heterogeneous catalysts, with promising potential both in electro- and photocatalysis. Their outstanding features, combining their crystalline structure, tunable porosity, and high specific surface areas with the versatile functionalization of their organic linker, make them a unique platform to target new functional materials. Owing to the strong incentive to develop sustainable and clean energy sources in the context of fossil fuels shortage and environmental pollution, water splitting into O2 and H2 through the photo­(electro)­chemical oxygen-evolution and hydrogen-evolution reactions, OER and HER, respectively, still requires new, efficient, and cheap catalytic materials. In that respect, recent research efforts have aimed at functionalizing MOFs toward OER and HER.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted immense research interest in the design of heterogeneous catalysts, with promising potential both in electro- and photocatalysis. Their outstanding features, combining their crystalline structure, tunable porosity, and high specific surface areas with the versatile functionalization of their organic linker, make them a unique platform to target new functional materials. Owing to the strong incentive to develop sustainable and clean energy sources in the context of fossil fuels shortage and environmental pollution, water splitting into O2 and H2 through the photo(electro)chemical oxygen-evolution and hydrogen-evolution reactions, OER and HER, respectively, still requires new, efficient, and cheap catalytic materials. In that respect, recent research efforts have aimed at functionalizing MOFs toward OER and HER.

elements.content: While significant advances have been made on the use of MOFs for HER, much fewer studies have been carried out toward OER, probably as a result of their frequent lack of stability under water-oxidation reaction conditions. The emergence of MOF-based solids for OER has been particularly driven by the motivation to handle catalysts containing earth-abundant elements rather than costly noble metals. Various strategies have been proposed to design MOF-based materials for electro- or photocatalytic OER. An early case was provided in electrocatalysis with the chemically robust cobalt–imidazolate, zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF)-9, where the Co nodes are catalytically active single sites. Another efficient strategy consists in immobilizing an OER catalyst into the pores of a MOF host, as exemplified with cobalt-based polyoxometalates (POMs) encapsulated in ZIF-8, MIL-101, or MIL-100. Other recent heterogeneous MOF-based electrocatalysts for OER include porphyrin-based MOFs, such as the free base porphyrin Pb-MOF or the PCN-224-Ni which contains a nickel porphyrin linker. While the above recent developments opened new avenues for using MOF materials for electrocatalytic OER purposes, their use for photocatalytic OER is currently more limited. A pioneer strategy for designing photocatalytically active MOFs was reported by Lin et al., whereby the zirconium-based UiO-67, namely, Zr6O4(OH)4(bpdc)6 (bpdc = biphenyl dicarboxylate), is used as a modular scaffold to perform OER. In this case, the MOF is functionalized with Ir-based bipyridine linkers capable of locally performing OER, whilst the rest of the MOF scaffold stays catalytically inactive.

elements.content: Since then, the use of MOFs as photosensitizers to yield light-harvesting frameworks has attracted ever-growing research efforts, making porphyrin-based MOFs an interesting subclass of solids for designing new biomimetic photosystems. However, the use of such MOFs in photocatalytic applications has been mostly reported for the reduction of CO2, with only scarce reports for visible light-driven photocatalytic OER so far. We recently reported the photosensitization of the [(PW9O34)2Co4(H2O)2]10– (P2W18Co4 ) POM catalyst by the porphyrins of the MOF-545, within the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 solid, which occurs under visible light irradiation. This provided a rare example of an “all-in-one” (porosity + light capture + catalysis) fully noble metal-free heterogeneous photocatalyst for OER (a,b). The unique activity of the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 photosystem was shown to benefit from key factors, such as the immobilization of the porphyrin as a ligand within the MOF’s scaffold, whereby the MOF plays the role of a solid-state photosensitizer. The porosity of the MOF allows facile diffusion of reactants and products. Finally, the confinement of catalytic POMs inside the MOF’s pores allows their stabilization, while the POM–MOF interface provides key components (OH, labile water molecules) relevant to the OER mechanism. Still, the reuse of such photosystems as powders in suspension requires centrifugations with potential loss of materials.

elements.content: Further strategies to develop thin films of such catalytically active MOFs are required in the perspective of novel forms of devices and technologies. They currently attract a great deal of attention in subfields ranging from optoelectronic devices, sensors to photo- and electrocatalysis. As MOFs are mostly obtained as powders, there is a strong incentive to deposit them on transparent conducting supports such as fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) or indium tin oxide (ITO) and to formulate them so that not only electronic transport can be improved but also easy-to-use and recyclable setups can be developed. Two kinds of strategies include in situ approaches, whereby the MOF is synthesized in the presence of the support (solvothermal synthesis, layer-by-layer, or liquid-phase epitaxy growth, electrodeposition), and ex situ approaches, whereby a presynthesized MOF is deposited on the support (spin coating, drop casting (DC), electrophoretic (EP) deposition).

They currently attract a great deal of attention in subfields ranging from optoelectronic devices, sensors to photo- and electrocatalysis. As MOFs are mostly obtained as powders, there is a strong incentive to deposit them on transparent conducting supports such as fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) or indium tin oxide (ITO) and to formulate them so that not only electronic transport can be improved but also easy-to-use and recyclable setups can be developed. Two kinds of strategies include in situ approaches, whereby the MOF is synthesized in the presence of the support (solvothermal synthesis, layer-by-layer, or liquid-phase epitaxy growth, electrodeposition), and ex situ approaches, whereby a presynthesized MOF is deposited on the support (spin coating, drop casting (DC), electrophoretic (EP) deposition).

elements.content: The development of MOF-based thin films for OER is a recently developing subfield. An early example is the study of Zhao et al., whereby nickel–cobalt MOF sheets with coordinatively unsaturated metal sites were shown to function as robust and highly active OER electrocatalysts. Also, the porphyrinic PCN-224-Ni was deposited on ITO by a solvothermal reaction and electrochemically investigated for OER in an aqueous solution. While thin films of porphyrinic MOFs have been the subject of very intense research efforts, reports of porphyrinic–MOF thin films for photocatalytic OER are rather scarce. Here, we thus considered investigating the thin-film deposition of our recently published P2W18Co4@MOF-545 composite using drop casting and electrophoretic deposition methods on ITO and evaluating its potential for photocatalytic OER. At this stage, ex situ deposition methods were preferred to in situ ones as they were easier to implement for our POM@MOF system. We discuss the two thin-film deposition methods and characterize the films for their electrochemical properties. Finally, we show that they behave as excellent photocatalysts for OER. The use of thin films is shown to be particularly advantageous, allowing easy reuse and characterizations.

elements.content: Microcrystalline MOF-545 and P2W18Co4@MOF-545 particles were synthesized via a solvothermal route according to a previously reported procedure (see ). Commercially available ITO-coated poly­(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) films were preferred to FTO-coated glass to facilitate further characterizations using X-ray spectroscopy. As illustrated in c, thin films of P2W18Co4@MOF-545 on ITO electrodes were prepared either in one step by drop casting P2W18Co4@MOF-545 directly on ITO (P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC) or using an electrophoretic deposition of the MOF (MOF-545-EP), followed by impregnation with the POM (P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP). For reference purposes (vide infra), MOF-545-DC was also prepared. In the case of electrophoretic deposition, MOF-545-EP films were obtained by dipping two face-to-face ITO electrodes into a toluene suspension of microcrystalline MOF-545 powder. Due to free carboxylate ligands at the MOF surface, particles bear a negatively charged surface. Applying a 45 V cell voltage between electrodes thus allowed the migration of MOF particles to the anode. The formed MOF-545-EP thin films were subsequently impregnated with an aqueous solution of the P2W18Co4 -POM to form the desired P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP (see ). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (a and S1) of MOF-545-EP, P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP, and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC show that both types of films consist of rod-shaped particles (1–2 μm length) characteristic of the sixfold symmetry of the structure. It is apparent that EP allows the formation of denser (∼20 μm thickness measured by profilometry) and more homogeneous films than the DC method for which MOF particles are more sparsely distributed on the ITO surface. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns collected on bulk P2W18Co4@MOF-545 and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP (Figure S2) confirm the good crystallinity with no additional peak found, although, due to the limited thickness of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP films, higher-angle peaks were enlarged and had smaller intensities, consistent with PXRD reported on thin films.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Microcrystalline MOF-545 and P2W18Co4@MOF-545 particles were synthesized via a solvothermal route according to a previously reported procedure (see ). Commercially available ITO-coated poly(ethylene terephthalate) (PET) films were preferred to FTO-coated glass to facilitate further characterizations using X-ray spectroscopy. As illustrated in c, thin films of P2W18Co4@MOF-545 on ITO electrodes were prepared either in one step by drop casting P2W18Co4@MOF-545 directly on ITO (P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC) or using an electrophoretic deposition of the MOF (MOF-545-EP), followed by impregnation with the POM (P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP). For reference purposes (vide infra), MOF-545-DC was also prepared. In the case of electrophoretic deposition, MOF-545-EP films were obtained by dipping two face-to-face ITO electrodes into a toluene suspension of microcrystalline MOF-545 powder. Due to free carboxylate ligands at the MOF surface, particles bear a negatively charged surface. Applying a 45 V cell voltage between electrodes thus allowed the migration of MOF particles to the anode. The formed MOF-545-EP thin films were subsequently impregnated with an aqueous solution of the P2W18Co4 -POM to form the desired P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP (see ). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images (a and S1) of MOF-545-EP, P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP, and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC show that both types of films consist of rod-shaped particles (1-2 μm length) characteristic of the sixfold symmetry of the structure. It is apparent that EP allows the formation of denser (~20 μm thickness measured by profilometry) and more homogeneous films than the DC method for which MOF particles are more sparsely distributed on the ITO surface. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns collected on bulk P2W18Co4@MOF-545 and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP (Figure S2) confirm the good crystallinity with no additional peak found, although, due to the limited thickness of P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP films, higher-angle peaks were enlarged and had smaller intensities, consistent with PXRD reported on thin films.

elements.content: Before deposition on ITO, the integrity of the POM component within the POM@MOF composite was checked on the bulk using NMR techniques. Liquid-state 31P NMR spectrum (Figure S3) of digested P2W18Co4@MOF-545 in a borate buffer at pH 10 showed a single thin peak at ∼1828 ppm, characteristic of P2W18Co4 , in agreement with those obtained from a solution of P2W18Co4 in a borate buffer at pH 8 and 10. Solid-state magic angle spinning 31P NMR (MAS-NMR) conducted on bulk P2W18Co4@MOF-545 showed an enlarged peak at ∼1700 ppm, consistent with previous measurements, while the absence of peak at around 0–10 ppm confirmed the absence of free phosphates and Co-free POMs. In addition, X-ray spectroscopy at the Co K-edge energy revealed no significant difference between P2W18Co4 or P2W18Co4@MOF-545 bulk powders and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP (b and S4).

Liquid-state 31P NMR spectrum (Figure S3) of digested P2W18Co4@MOF-545 in a borate buffer at pH 10 showed a single thin peak at ~1828 ppm, characteristic of P2W18Co4 , in agreement with those obtained from a solution of P2W18Co4  in a borate buffer at pH 8 and 10. Solid-state magic angle spinning 31P NMR (MAS-NMR) conducted on bulk P2W18Co4@MOF-545 showed an enlarged peak at ~1700 ppm, consistent with previous measurements, while the absence of peak at around 0-10 ppm confirmed the absence of free phosphates and Co-free POMs. In addition, X-ray spectroscopy at the Co K-edge energy revealed no significant difference between P2W18Co4  or P2W18Co4@MOF-545 bulk powders and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP (b and S4).

elements.content: In agreement with the literature, prevalent Fourier-transformed (FT) peaks of the P2W18Co4 POM and P2W18Co4@MOF-545 bulk powders were assigned to Co–O (1.6 Å), Co–P and Co–Co (2.9 Å), and Co–W (3.4 Å) atom pairs (Figure S5 and Table S1). FT EXAFS data on thin films are broader and less defined than those on bulk powder due to the small amount of material exposed to the beam combined with the relatively low concentration of cobalt atoms in the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 composite. Still, the main peak at 1.5 Å characteristic of the first coordination sphere (Co–O) is close to that observed for the bulk material and the X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra differ from the one obtained for diverse cobalt oxides (Figure S6), providing evidence of the POM’s integrity immobilized in MOF-545.

elements.content: The impregnation of P2W18Co4 in MOF-545-EP thin films was performed in identical conditions as those for preparing the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 bulk powder further deposited on DC thin films, for which we determined the following formula: [Zr6O16H18]3[C48H26N4O8]6·[P2W18O70Co4H4]0.6·78H2O, leading to surface densities of 16 and 1.5 nmol cm–2 on P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC, respectively (see ).
elements.clean_text: The impregnation of P2W18Co4  in MOF-545-EP thin films was performed in identical conditions as those for preparing the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 bulk powder further deposited on DC thin films, for which we determined the following formula: [Zr6O16H18]3[C48H26N4O8]6⋅[P2W18O70Co4H4]0.6⋅78H2O, leading to surface densities of 16 and 1.5 nmol cm-2 on P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC, respectively (see ).

elements.content: The electrochemical behavior of P2W18Co4 , P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP, and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC was studied. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) as well as linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were conducted in an 80 mM borate buffer at pH 8, at which both the MOF and POM components are stable. CVs were measured between 0.65 and 1.85 V vs RHE. The CVs displayed a characteristic wave assigned to CoII/CoIII redox processes of the Co centers of the POM (Figure S7). Half-wave potential is similar for both the POM in solution over a bare ITO electrode and the thin films, measured at 1.35 V. Furthermore, Figure S8 displays CVs of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC as a function of the scan rate, whereby the linear dependence of the peak current intensity with respect to the scan rate is consistent with a surface-controlled redox process.
elements.clean_text: The electrochemical behavior of P2W18Co4 , P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP, and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC was studied. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) as well as linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were conducted in an 80 mM borate buffer at pH 8, at which both the MOF and POM components are stable. CVs were measured between 0.65 and 1.85 V vs RHE. The CVs displayed a characteristic wave assigned to CoII/CoIII redox processes of the Co centers of the POM (Figure S7). Half-wave potential is similar for both the POM in solution over a bare ITO electrode and the thin films, measured at 1.35 V. Furthermore, Figure S8 displays CVs of P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC as a function of the scan rate, whereby the linear dependence of the peak current intensity with respect to the scan rate is consistent with a surface-controlled redox process.

elements.content: For both EP and DC deposition methods, the LSVs show similar electrochemical trends going from bare ITO to MOF-545 thin films to P2W18Co4@MOF-545 (c). On the bare ITO electrode, water-oxidation reaction starts at a potential of 1.88 V. For both MOF-545-EP and MOF-545-DC, the MOF coating has an insulator effect that lowers the current density and does not show any catalytic effect. By contrast, thin films of the full POM@MOF composite show a catalytic wave starting at +1.62 V for both P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC, in agreement with literature and LSVs conducted on a 5 mM P2W18Co4 solution (Figure S9), thus showing an overpotential for OER of 390 mV. To confirm the electrocatalytic OER of the thin films, controlled-potential electrolysis (CPE) experiments were conducted at 1.88 V vs RHE in an 80 mM borate buffer solution at pH 8 (d). A stable current density was obtained for 2 h and reproduced after two more cycles (same charge passed; see for details). Blank experiments conducted on either bare ITO electrode or MOF-545 thin films (Figure S10) led to negligible current intensities when compared to those of POM@MOF thin films. The higher current densities observed for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP (∼350 μA cm–2) with respect to P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC (∼200 μA cm–2) may be explained by the larger quantities of POM@MOF catalyst deposited on EP films when compared to DC ones (1 order of magnitude difference). The first evidence for the production of O2 is the formation of bubbles at the electrode surface triggered by the application of the potential. O2 production was measured over the experiments by gas chromatography (a and S11) and was shown to occur linearly over time, consistent with the stable current observed during catalysis. Faradic yields calculated after 2 h of reaction are close to 100% for both P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC. The comparison of electrocatalytic performances of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP points toward the better activity of DC thin films: turnover numbers (TONs) and turnover frequencies (TOFs) calculated over 2 h amount, respectively, to 527 and 73 × 10–3 s–1 for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and 2250 and 310 × 10–3 s–1 for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC. The remarkably higher performances of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC with respect to P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP may be attributed to the larger thickness of EP films (∼20 μm) when compared to that of DC films (crystallite size of ∼1 μm). Consequently, an important proportion of POM@MOF crystallites on top of the film, i.e., far from the conductive ITO support, may not participate in the electrocatalysis as part of an insulating layer of materials in P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC, a higher amount of active sites of the catalytic POM are available owing to a higher dispersion of the sample.
elements.clean_text: For both EP and DC deposition methods, the LSVs show similar electrochemical trends going from bare ITO to MOF-545 thin films to P2W18Co4@MOF-545 (c). On the bare ITO electrode, water-oxidation reaction starts at a potential of 1.88 V. For both MOF-545-EP and MOF-545-DC, the MOF coating has an insulator effect that lowers the current density and does not show any catalytic effect. By contrast, thin films of the full POM@MOF composite show a catalytic wave starting at +1.62 V for both P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC, in agreement with literature and LSVs conducted on a 5 mM P2W18Co4  solution (Figure S9), thus showing an overpotential for OER of 390 mV. To confirm the electrocatalytic OER of the thin films, controlled-potential electrolysis (CPE) experiments were conducted at 1.88 V vs RHE in an 80 mM borate buffer solution at pH 8 (d). A stable current density was obtained for 2 h and reproduced after two more cycles (same charge passed; see  for details). Blank experiments conducted on either bare ITO electrode or MOF-545 thin films (Figure S10) led to negligible current intensities when compared to those of POM@MOF thin films. elements.content: As a reference, CPE conducted on MOF-545-EP and MOF-545-DC soaked into a 5 μM Co­(NO3)2 solution led to current densities of only 50 μA cm–2 (Figure S10). The current densities were 4–7 (DC and EP, respectively) times lower than the POM@MOF thin films, although the total amount of cobalt ions in solution exceeded that in the POM@MOF (75 nmol vs 23 nmol in EP films). This hints that free cobalt ions are less catalytically active in these conditions than the immobilized P2W18Co4 POM. This also confirms that the observed catalytic activity may not be attributed to leaching and to degradation of the POM into free cobalt ions in solution.

elements.content: The photocatalytic OER activities of the two types of thin films were studied under visible light irradiation in pH 8 borate buffer using sodium persulfate (Na2S2O8) as the electron acceptor and the MOF’s porphyrin ligand as the photosensitizer. As shown in b, O2 was formed immediately upon exposure to light and increased linearly with time.

elements.content: For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP, a plateau is reached after a 1 h reaction. The addition of a fresh solution of Na2S2O8 resulted in a restart of O2 production with the same initial TOF (Figure S12). As evidenced previously, these results show that the system’s limitation originates from the depletion of the electron acceptor and proves the stability of the catalytic material. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC, oxygen production slows down but still occurs within the 2 h of the experiment. As control experiments, we found that POM@MOF thin films did not show any significant catalytic activity either in the absence of light (Table S2, entries 1 and 2) or of a sacrificial electron acceptor (Table S2, entries 3 and 4). Similarly, the absence of the POM catalyst in MOF-545-DC or MOF-545-EP did not allow any significant O2 production (Table S2, entries 5 and 6). Finally, the activity of MOF-545-DC or MOF-545-EP soaked in 5 μM CoII solution (Table S2, entries 7 and 8) is far lower than that of the corresponding P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545 films. This indicates that free CoII ions are much less active than the immobilized P2W18Co4 POM.

elements.content: The two types of thin films exhibit significantly different photocatalytic activities during OER, pointing toward a much higher performance of DC-type thin films. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP, the TON after 2 h amounts to 403 and the TOF over the first 30 min to 134 10–3 s–1. The corresponding values for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC are much higher and amount to 1600 (TON) and 467 10–3 s–1 (TOF). Here, we interpret such differences as a result of the efficient illumination of the POM@MOF photosystem in DC thin films, whereby all particles deposited on ITO are exposed to light, while in the thicker (multiple-layered) EP films, only the sublayer of POM@MOF particles indeed exposed to light is functional. Remarkably, both types of films exhibit higher photocatalytic activities than P2W18Co4@MOF-545 illuminated in suspension (b). This may be again explained not only by the lower quantities of catalyst deposited on films with respect to that in suspensionwhich tends to increase the calculated TONbut also by a less efficient exposure of crystallites to light when in suspension (random orientation of crystallites, light diffusion by the suspension). A schematic illustration of such differences between the suspensions, DC, and EP films upon light illumination is proposed in .

elements.content: Schematic representation of the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 photosystem under various setups upon light illumination: (a) in suspension, light capture by the crystallites is not optimal (random orientation of crystallites, light diffusion); (b) as a thick layer on ITO obtained using electrophoresis (EP); the absorption of light is limited to the fraction of the crystallites in contact with ITO; (c) deposited on ITO by drop casting; DC allows depositing small amounts of POM@MOF dispersed on ITO so that all crystallites may be illuminated.

elements.content: When compared to existing related published photosystems, the catalytic performances of the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 films outperform those reported for homogeneous P2W18Co4 -based photosystems (TON of 75). They are also much higher than those reported for suspensions of other composites P2W18Co4 @MIL-101­(Cr) (estimated TON of 13) and P2W18Co4 @MIL-100­(Fe) (estimated TON of 16) as well as those of POM-free MIL-101­(Fe) MOFs (TON of 27). It is worth highlighting here that the use of the external [Ru­(bpy)3]2+ photosensitizer is avoided in the present POM@MOF photosystem in contrast to those cited above.

elements.content:
To investigate the stability of the immobilized P2W18Co4 POM in the POM@MOF thin films during electrocatalysis or photocatalysis, various characterizations were made on both types of thin films.

First, dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements were done on both the electrolyte solutions after CPE and the photocatalytic reaction solution. They showed no particles of size lower than 100 nm, allowing us to exclude the formation of cobalt oxide nanoparticles during the reaction. These results confirm the absence of leaching of the immobilized P2W18Co4 POM, which is indeed responsible for the observed catalytic properties of the P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545 composite. Second, CVs were measured on P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC after CPE or photocatalysis, and compared to the original ones, showing the persistence of the reversible wave at 1.35 V vs RHE in all cases (Figure S13). Finally, EXAFS–XANES spectra collected at the Co K-edge energy for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC ( and S14) and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP (Figure S15) after 2 h photocatalytic or electrocatalytic experiments showed only a slight shift of the main edge position toward higher energies (1 eV) with respect to the initial material. Given that the pre-edge region does not present any change in intensity or any new peak (a), we exclude a net change in the Co oxidation state. We rather attribute this shift to changes in the Co local environment and exclude any drastic modification in its structure. This is furthermore assessed by the similarities between the FT-EXAFS before/after catalysis (b), indicating that the POM’s integrity is maintained. Also, Raman spectroscopy performed on P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP shows that the MOF vibrational spectrum is marginally impacted by the POM guest (Figure S16) and remains unchanged after photocatalysis (Figure S17), thus corroborating the integrity of the MOF host upon OER. Finally, SEM images of the electrodes’ surface after electro- or photocatalysis showed no difference with the surfaces before catalysis (Figures S18 and S19). All of the above characterizations yield converging conclusions toward the POM@MOF photosystem stability in thin films upon OER catalysis.

elements.content: In this work, we have reported the optimization of the catalytic performances of a thin-film POM@MOF photosystem for OER, comparing two different techniques of deposition on ITO (drop casting and electrophoresis). With the long-term goal to develop robust and recyclable heterogeneous noble metal-free photosystems in the field of energy, the present work shows that POM@MOF composites deposited into thin films offer an outstanding benefit in terms of photocatalytic efficiency while allowing their integration into easy-to-use devices. Indeed, the TONs for the photocatalytic O2 production obtained with the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 composite are greatly enhanced using thin films when compared to those obtained with the POM@MOF bulk composite in suspension, with estimated TONs of 1600 (DC) and 403 (EP) vs 70. The relative performances of thin films and suspension (DC > EP > suspension) may be rationalized by the optimal illumination of the POM@MOF crystallites in DC-type thin films.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we have reported the optimization of the catalytic performances of a thin-film POM@MOF photosystem for OER, comparing two different techniques of deposition on ITO (drop casting and electrophoresis). With the long-term goal to develop robust and recyclable heterogeneous noble metal-free photosystems in the field of energy, the present work shows that POM@MOF composites deposited into thin films offer an outstanding benefit in terms of photocatalytic efficiency while allowing their integration into easy-to-use devices. Indeed, the TONs for the photocatalytic O2 production obtained with the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 composite are greatly enhanced using thin films when compared to those obtained with the POM@MOF bulk composite in suspension, with estimated TONs of 1600 (DC) and 403 (EP) vs 70. The relative performances of thin films and suspension (DC > EP > suspension) may be rationalized by the optimal illumination of the POM@MOF crystallites in DC-type thin films.

elements.content: Importantly, state-of-the-art techniques provide, for the first time, evidence for the integrity of the POM catalyst in POM@MOF thin films after electrocatalysis and photocatalysis. Overall, the above results highlight the performances of porphyrin-based MOFs as light-sensitive hosts for the heterogenization of molecular catalysts when coupled with their shaping into thin films for developing heterogeneous photosystems performing key reactions of interest. It is hoped that this work will also promote ongoing interest in the field toward the in-depth characterization of catalysts, which is essential for rationally designing efficient and selective catalysts for OER.

elements.content: Na10[(PW9O34)2Co4(H2O)2] (P2W18Co4 ), tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­porphyrin (TCPP-H 2 ), MOF-545, and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545 were synthesized according to reported procedures. All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. ITO-plated glass electrodes were purchased from SOLEMS and cut to reach a 6 × 20 mm2 size.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Na10[(PW9O34)2Co4(H2O)2] (P2W18Co4 ), tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin (TCPP-H  2 ), MOF-545, and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545  were synthesized according to reported procedures. All other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. ITO-plated glass electrodes were purchased from SOLEMS and cut to reach a 6 × 20 mm2 size.

elements.content: P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP was prepared in two steps to avoid exposing the POM to high voltage. To form MOF-545-EP, two ITO electrodes were immersed 3 mm apart in a colloidal suspension containing 1 mg of MOF-545 in 4 mL of toluene. A 45 V cell voltage was then applied between the two electrodes for 30 min three times consecutively and with no agitation, the MOF suspension being renewed between each cycle. P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP was then obtained by immersing the MOF-545-EP electrodes in a 5 mM solution of P 2 W 18 Co 4 in an 80 mM B­(OH)3 pH 8 buffer solution for 5 h. The EP thin films were carefully washed with water to allow the release of POMs adsorbed at the surface of MOF particles. P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC was drop casted (10 μL) from a suspension of 1 mg of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545 in 1 mL of ethanol on an ITO electrode of area 36 mm2 and allowed to dry at room temperature for 10 min. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC, the material mass was calculated at 0.01 mg according to the concentration and volume of the deposited drop. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP, the mass of deposited material was measured by weighting the material over 20 electrodes prepared in identical conditions, leading to an average deposited MOF amount of 0.11 mg. Using the chemical formula ([Zr6O18H18]3[C48H26O8N4]6 [P2W18O70Co4H4]0.6·78H2O) determined for the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 powder, P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC contains 0.53 nmol and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP 5.8 nmol of P2W18Co4 , equivalent to 1.5 and 16 nmol cm–2 of POM, respectively.
elements.clean_text:

To form MOF-545-EP, two ITO electrodes were immersed 3 mm apart in a colloidal suspension containing 1 mg of MOF-545 in 4 mL of toluene. A 45 V cell voltage was then applied between the two electrodes for 30 min three times consecutively and with no agitation, the MOF suspension being renewed between each cycle. P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP was then obtained by immersing the MOF-545-EP electrodes in a 5 mM solution of P  2  W  18  Co  4  in an 80 mM B(OH)3 pH 8 buffer solution for 5 h. The EP thin films were carefully washed with water to allow the release of POMs adsorbed at the surface of MOF particles. P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC was drop casted (10 μL) from a suspension of 1 mg of P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545 in 1 mL of ethanol on an ITO electrode of area 36 mm2 and allowed to dry at room temperature for 10 min. For P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC, the material mass was calculated at 0.01 mg according to the concentration and volume of the deposited drop. For P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP, the mass of deposited material was measured by weighting the material over 20 electrodes prepared in identical conditions, leading to an average deposited MOF amount of 0.11 mg. Using the chemical formula ([Zr6O18H18]3[C48H26O8N4]6 [P2W18O70Co4H4]0.6⋅78H2O) determined for the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 powder, P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC contains 0.53 nmol and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP 5.8 nmol of P2W18Co4 , equivalent to 1.5 and 16 nmol cm-2 of POM, respectively.

elements.content: Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 30 ATR 6700 FT spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained on a Bruker D5000 diffractometer using Cu radiation (1.54059 Å). Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurements were performed on a JEOL JSM 5800LV apparatus. X-ray absorption spectra were recorded on the SAMBA beamline of SOLEIL at a ring energy of 2.75 GeV and a current of 500 mA. The incident energy was selected using a Si(222) double-crystal monochromator and calibrated to the first inflection point of a Co foil (E = 7709 eV). Measurements were performed in fluorescence mode using a Bruker fluorescence detector. The optical properties of P2W18Co4@MOF-545 and MOF-545 may be found in ref . Raman spectra were measured on a home-made Raman spectrometer at 532 nm, the spectrum being acquired with a fiber-coupled spectrometer coupled to a charge-coupled device (CCD) camera (IsoPlane SCT 320 mounted with a PIXIS, using a 1800 lines grating; Princeton Inst.). An interferential filter was used to cut the elastic scattering. The spectral resolution was set to 6 cm–1. The laser power was adjusted to about 1–2 mW on the sample to avoid laser damage. Solid-state 31P MAS NMR was recorded on a Bruker Avance 500 MHz spectrometer (B 0 = 11.7 T). The sample was packed in a 2.5 mm zirconia rotor and spun at a 30 kHz MAS rate. The spectrum was recorded using a rotor-synchronized Hahn-echo sequence 90°−τ–180°−τ. The 90° pulse length was 2.3 μs, the τ delay was 33 μs, and the recycle delay was 0.1 s. The spectrum was an accumulation of ca. 105 000 transients. Solution 31P NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 400 apparatus at 162.3 MHz. Chemical shifts were referenced to 85% H3PO4.

Physical Methods

Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on a Nicolet 30 ATR 6700 FT spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were obtained on a Bruker D5000 diffractometer using Cu radiation (1.54059 Å). Energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) measurements were performed on a JEOL JSM 5800LV apparatus. X-ray absorption spectra were recorded on the SAMBA beamline of SOLEIL at a ring energy of 2.75 GeV and a current of 500 mA. The incident energy was selected using a Si(222) double-crystal monochromator and calibrated to the first inflection point of a Co foil (E = 7709 eV). Measurements were performed in fluorescence mode using a Bruker fluorescence detector. The optical properties of P2W18Co4@MOF-545 and MOF-545 may be found in ref . Raman spectra were measured on a home-made Raman spectrometer at 532 nm, the spectrum being acquired with a fiber-coupled spectrometer coupled to a charge-coupled device (CCD) camera (IsoPlane SCT 320 mounted with a PIXIS, using a 1800 lines grating; Princeton Inst.). elements.content: Similar conditions as those used for studying the OER catalytic performances of suspensions of P2W18Co4@MOF-545 were used to ensure the MOF and POM’s stability. Electrodes were fixed to a wall of a quartz cuvette with a volume of 4.2 mL. The cuvette was then filled with 2 mL of a 5 mM Na2S2O8 solution in 80 mM B­(OH)3 pH 8 buffer, sealed, thoroughly degassed using nitrogen, and finally placed in a temperature-controlled block at 20 °C. The thin films were irradiated with a 280 W xenon light source equipped with a 420 nm filter and a water infrared filter. Oxygen produced was measured by analyzing 50 μL aliquots from the cuvette’s headspace by gas chromatography on a Shimadzu GC-2014 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a Quadrex column. O2 quantification was achieved accordingly to the corresponding calibration curves.

Photocatalytic Activity Measurements

Similar conditions as those used for studying the OER catalytic performances of suspensions of P2W18Co4@MOF-545 were used to ensure the MOF and POM's stability. Electrodes were fixed to a wall of a quartz cuvette with a volume of 4.2 mL. The cuvette was then filled with 2 mL of a 5 mM Na2S2O8 solution in 80 mM B(OH)3 pH 8 buffer, sealed, thoroughly degassed using nitrogen, and finally placed in a temperature-controlled block at 20 °C. The thin films were irradiated with a 280 W xenon light source equipped with a 420 nm filter and a water infrared filter. Oxygen produced was measured by analyzing 50 μL aliquots from the cuvette's headspace by gas chromatography on a Shimadzu GC-2014 equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a Quadrex column. O2 quantification was achieved accordingly to the corresponding calibration curves.

elements.content: Electrochemical studies were conducted in similar conditions as the photocatalytic experiments using an SP 300 potentiostat (Bio-Logic Science Instruments SAS). All of the electrochemical experiments were performed at room temperature in a 15 mL, 80 mM B­(OH)3 pH 8 buffer using ultrapure water produced by a Millipore system (18.2 MΩ at 25 °C) and 1 M NaOH to adjust pH. Solutions were deaerated using nitrogen gas. CVs and controlled-potential electrolysis were carried out at room temperature in a gas-tight two-compartment electrochemical cell. Cathodic and anodic compartments were separated via a glass frit of fine porosity. The counter electrode was a platinum wire, the reference electrode was a saturated Ag/AgCl/KCl electrode separated from the electrolyte by a salt bridge, and the working electrode was the relevant ITO-coated glass electrode. The electrochemical surface area was estimated by measuring the geometrical area of the electrode. Electric contact between the ITO surface and the potentiostat was made through copper tape. Production of oxygen in the anodic headspace gas was measured using the same methods as for photocatalytic activity measurements. Recyclability experiments (three cycles) were performed obtaining the same current densities and charge passed for 2 h. The electrode was removed, rinsed with ethanol, and immersed in a new deaerated buffer solution. All TONs and TOFs were estimated by normalizing the production of O2 with the number of nmol of POM.

elements.content: X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy analyses were done at SAMBA beamline, Synchrotron SOLEIL, France. The storage ring was operated with a 2.75 GeV electron energy ring, 500 mA current, and multibunch mode. Thin films or powders pressed into pellets of P2W18Co4 , P2W18Co4@MOF-545, P2W18Co4@MOF-545-DC, and P2W18Co4@MOF-545-EP were analyzed at 77 K using a N2 cryostat. X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectroscopy spectra were collected at the Co K-edge (7709 eV) between 7500 and 8335 eV. Acquisitions were done in fluorescence mode using a Ge multipixel fluorescence detector (Canberra). All spectra were processed using Athena featured in Demeter Software Package.

cln_elements.content: P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP was prepared in two steps to avoid exposing the POM to high voltage. To form MOF-545-EP, two ITO electrodes were immersed 3 mm apart in a colloidal suspension containing 1 mg of MOF-545 in 4 mL of toluene. A 45 V cell voltage was then applied between the two electrodes for 30 min three times consecutively and with no agitation, the MOF suspension being renewed between each cycle. P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP was then obtained by immersing the MOF-545-EP electrodes in a 5 mM solution of P 2 W 18 Co 4 in an 80 mM B­(OH)3 pH 8 buffer solution for 5 h. The EP thin films were carefully washed with water to allow the release of POMs adsorbed at the surface of MOF particles. P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC was drop casted (10 μL) from a suspension of 1 mg of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545 in 1 mL of ethanol on an ITO electrode of area 36 mm2 and allowed to dry at room temperature for 10 min. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC, the material mass was calculated at 0.01 mg according to the concentration and volume of the deposited drop. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP, the mass of deposited material was measured by weighting the material over 20 electrodes prepared in identical conditions, leading to an average deposited MOF amount of 0.11 mg. Using the chemical formula ([Zr6O18H18]3[C48H26O8N4]6 [P2W18O70Co4H4]0.6·78H2O) determined for the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 powder, P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC contains 0.53 nmol and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP 5.8 nmol of P2W18Co4 , equivalent to 1.5 and 16 nmol cm–2 of POM, respectively.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thin Films' Preparation

 P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP was prepared in two steps to avoid exposing the POM to high voltage. To form MOF-545-EP, two ITO electrodes were immersed 3 mm apart in a colloidal suspension containing 1 mg of MOF-545 in 4 mL of toluene. A 45 V cell voltage was then applied between the two electrodes for 30 min three times consecutively and with no agitation, the MOF suspension being renewed between each cycle. P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP was then obtained by immersing the MOF-545-EP electrodes in a 5 mM solution of P  2  W  18  Co  4  in an 80 mM B(OH)3 pH 8 buffer solution for 5 h. The EP thin films were carefully washed with water to allow the release of POMs adsorbed at the surface of MOF particles. P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC was drop casted (10 μL) from a suspension of 1 mg of P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545 in 1 mL of ethanol on an ITO electrode of area 36 mm2 and allowed to dry at room temperature for 10 min. For P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC, the material mass was calculated at 0.01 mg according to the concentration and volume of the deposited drop. For P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP, the mass of deposited material was measured by weighting the material over 20 electrodes prepared in identical conditions, leading to an average deposited MOF amount of 0.11 mg. Using the chemical formula ([Zr6O18H18]3[C48H26O8N4]6 [P2W18O70Co4H4]0.6⋅78H2O) determined for the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 powder, P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-DC contains 0.53 nmol and P  2  W  18  Co  4  @MOF-545-EP 5.8 nmol of P2W18Co4 , equivalent to 1.5 and 16 nmol cm-2 of POM, respectively.

cln_elements.content:
The electrochemical behavior of P2W18Co4 , P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP, and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC was studied. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) as well as linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) measurements were conducted in an 80 mM borate buffer at pH 8, at which both the MOF and POM components are stable. CVs were measured between 0.65 and 1.85 V vs RHE. The CVs displayed a characteristic wave assigned to CoII/CoIII redox processes of the Co centers of the POM (Figure S7). Half-wave potential is similar for both the POM in solution over a bare ITO electrode and the thin films, measured at 1.35 V. Furthermore, Figure S8 displays CVs of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC as a function of the scan rate, whereby the linear dependence of the peak current intensity with respect to the scan rate is consistent with a surface-controlled redox process.

For both EP and DC deposition methods, the LSVs show similar electrochemical trends going from bare ITO to MOF-545 thin films to P2W18Co4@MOF-545 (c). On the bare ITO electrode, water-oxidation reaction starts at a potential of 1.88 V. For both MOF-545-EP and MOF-545-DC, the MOF coating has an insulator effect that lowers the current density and does not show any catalytic effect. By contrast, thin films of the full POM@MOF composite show a catalytic wave starting at +1.62 V for both P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC, in agreement with literature and LSVs conducted on a 5 mM P2W18Co4 solution (Figure S9), thus showing an overpotential for OER of 390 mV. To confirm the electrocatalytic OER of the thin films, controlled-potential electrolysis (CPE) experiments were conducted at 1.88 V vs RHE in an 80 mM borate buffer solution at pH 8 (d). A stable current density was obtained for 2 h and reproduced after two more cycles (same charge passed; see for details). Blank experiments conducted on either bare ITO electrode or MOF-545 thin films (Figure S10) led to negligible current intensities when compared to those of POM@MOF thin films. The higher current densities observed for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP (∼350 μA cm–2) with respect to P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC (∼200 μA cm–2) may be explained by the larger quantities of POM@MOF catalyst deposited on EP films when compared to DC ones (1 order of magnitude difference). The first evidence for the production of O2 is the formation of bubbles at the electrode surface triggered by the application of the potential. O2 production was measured over the experiments by gas chromatography (a and S11) and was shown to occur linearly over time, consistent with the stable current observed during catalysis. Faradic yields calculated after 2 h of reaction are close to 100% for both P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC. The comparison of electrocatalytic performances of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC and P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP points toward the better activity of DC thin films: turnover numbers (TONs) and turnover frequencies (TOFs) calculated over 2 h amount, respectively, to 527 and 73 × 10–3 s–1 for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and 2250 and 310 × 10–3 s–1 for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC. The remarkably higher performances of P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC with respect to P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP may be attributed to the larger thickness of EP films (∼20 μm) when compared to that of DC films (crystallite size of ∼1 μm). Consequently, an important proportion of POM@MOF crystallites on top of the film, i.e., far from the conductive ITO support, may not participate in the electrocatalysis as part of an insulating layer of materials in P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC, a higher amount of active sites of the catalytic POM are available owing to a higher dispersion of the sample.

The two types of thin films exhibit significantly different photocatalytic activities during OER, pointing toward a much higher performance of DC-type thin films. For P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP, the TON after 2 h amounts to 403 and the TOF over the first 30 min to 134 10–3 s–1. The corresponding values for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC are much higher and amount to 1600 (TON) and 467 10–3 s–1 (TOF). Here, we interpret such differences as a result of the efficient illumination of the POM@MOF photosystem in DC thin films, whereby all particles deposited on ITO are exposed to light, while in the thicker (multiple-layered) EP films, only the sublayer of POM@MOF particles indeed exposed to light is functional. Remarkably, both types of films exhibit higher photocatalytic activities than P2W18Co4@MOF-545 illuminated in suspension (b). This may be again explained not only by the lower quantities of catalyst deposited on films with respect to that in suspensionwhich tends to increase the calculated TONbut also by a less efficient exposure of crystallites to light when in suspension (random orientation of crystallites, light diffusion by the suspension). A schematic illustration of such differences between the suspensions, DC, and EP films upon light illumination is proposed in .

Recyclability was further investigated in photocatalysis. A significant advantage of thin films is the convenient and easy recollection for additional runs. shows that the POM@MOF may be reused in another photocatalytic run, with only a small loss in activity (5% for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-EP and 16% for P 2 W 18 Co 4 @MOF-545-DC).

Conclusions

In this work, we have reported the optimization of the catalytic performances of a thin-film POM@MOF photosystem for OER, comparing two different techniques of deposition on ITO (drop casting and electrophoresis). With the long-term goal to develop robust and recyclable heterogeneous noble metal-free photosystems in the field of energy, the present work shows that POM@MOF composites deposited into thin films offer an outstanding benefit in terms of photocatalytic efficiency while allowing their integration into easy-to-use devices. Indeed, the TONs for the photocatalytic O2 production obtained with the P2W18Co4@MOF-545 composite are greatly enhanced using thin films when compared to those obtained with the POM@MOF bulk composite in suspension, with estimated TONs of 1600 (DC) and 403 (EP) vs 70. The relative performances of thin films and suspension (DC > EP > suspension) may be rationalized by the optimal illumination of the POM@MOF crystallites in DC-type thin films.
